ANNIE.raw_line: What voice?We didn't hear anything.Sorry. Come on. Dinner. Annie leads Karin inside.Nape.Nope. You really hearing voices?Ah. God?What'd it say?If you build what, who will come?Ooh, I hate it when that happens.Ray?Karin, if you're finished, get your coat and school bag. Let's go. Karin bolts from the table.Far out. She takes off her coat and kisses Ray as he takes-the car keys and heads outside. Annie sits at the kitchen table.What if the voice calls while you're gone?Right. He exits. She grins, turns on the TV and watches Harvey.Yo, Ray! Food!Hiya, cutie. Ray climbs up the steps, accepts her kiss, and instead of following her into the house, pulls her down with him onto the swing. He takes-her hand and looks into her eyes.You heard the voice again.Get out of here!We're going to have to burn you at the stake if this keeps up.Hey, you don't suppose this could be like an acid flashback, do you?Maybe you will someday, and it's a flash forward.You're subscribing to the Enquirer.Oooh, why do I not think this is a good thing?You're kidding.Boy, I thought my family was crazy, but this...this is the craziest thing I've ever heard.I mean, Shoeless Joe, he's...And he's the one they suspended, right?He still dead?You know what amazes me? No one could ever get you to believe in astrology, or ESP, or reincarnation, or heaven, or any of that stuff. But this...I think this shows real personal growth, Ray.Oh, sweetie. I hope you know that even though I make jokes, I'm going to visit you every month wherever they put you. He offers her a weak smile and exits.If I did, I'd forgotten it. Ray sits up in the dark.Wait a minute, Bosco. Are you actually thinking of doing this?What's your father got to do with this? Ray tries to picture his father in his mind. He speaks softly, but the words obviously have a great deal of meaning for him.Yes. He smiles wanly. She touches his face lovingly.I also think that if you feel you really have to do this... then you should do it. They hold each other's gaze, and Ray cannot remember when he has loved her so much. He takes her in his arms. Outside their window, the field of corn lies waiting.That's the first time I've ever seen you smile as you mentioned your father. Ray considers that.Come on, you. Bed time. Annie hoists Karin on her shoulders with a grunt, and the three climb their way down the bleachers. Ray's hand steadies Annie as she takes one of the steps.That's what I like about it.Not completely. She looks out over the baseball field.It's a good baseball field, Ray.Any sign?Well, given how much less acreage we have for corn, I'd say we'll probably .almost break even.We've spent all our savings on that field.We'll put up some coffee. You go ahead. Ray takes a breath and steps out onto the veranda. The night sky seems close enough to touch.Would you like to come inside'?Where's he going?Since when is there a door in the fence?You bet your ass we are.You misplaced the house once.What???He doesn't drink, and he doesn't beat me, okay? Now I'll grant you, he has gotten me to worship Satan with him, but just a little. Her mother gasps.Kidding... I'm kidding! Her family has no sense of humor about this whatsoever.I think we need more cheese. She goes into the kitchen, and when she has rounded the corner, she raises her eyes to heaven and mutters:Families.Ray? Mom's leaving.You don't see it?They couldn't see it.Ray! Dinner!Come on, wash up. We've got a PTA meeting after dinner. They're talking about banning books again. Really subversive books like, Wizard of Oz, Diary of Anne Frank --- She notices Ray is strangely silent.What happened to you?Oh Lord, you don't have to build a football field now, do you?Ease whose pain?Shoeless Joe's?One of the other players?This is a very non-specific voice you've got out there, Ray, and he's really starting to piss me off. Ray nods as Annie serves the meal in silence.Fascist. I'd like to ease her pain. Ray is still lost in thought.I read it four times. Funniest book I ever read.No. I think you had two Fifties, and moved right on to the Seventies.Now there's an intelligent response.All right Beulah, you wanna step outside?!? Huh? The other woman takes a half-step backward. No one has ever seen sweet Annie like this.I got a better idea. Let's put it to a vote. Come on! Who's for Eva Braunhere? Who wants to burn books? Who wants to piss on the Constitution of the United Sates? Anybody? The majority who had sided with the book-banner wants to vote for censorship, but under these terms just can't raise their arms. Little Annie is on a roll, now.All right. Now: who's for The Bill of Rights? Come on...who thinks freedom's a pretty good thing? Let's see those hands. Some people start raising their hands.Who thinks we have to stand up to the kind of censorship they have in Russia? Reluctantly, just about everyone raises their hands. Annie is thrilled.There you go. All right, America! I'm proud of you. I mean it. You're beautiful!We gotta go. Ray pulls her from the room. Each is proud as hell, each for a different reason.Oh Ray, was that great, or what? it was like the Sixties again.Ray, I just halted the spread of neo-facism in America, and you're talking about ---What about him?How do you know that?What's his pain?Then how are you supposed to ease it?Ray...(tries to putRight. So what's it got to do with baseball?-Wow. He gives her a "See? What'd I tell you?" look.What can I say... Big wow, but..what's it got to do with baseball? They are standing by their car.Mmm. Some kind of team sport?That's sad...Oh my God!Sorry.So to ease his pain, you have to take him to a ball game?Ray, this is nuttier than building the field.I'm sorry, pal, but I have to nip this one in the bud. We are having moderate to heavy financial difficulties here. You cannot take off for Boston while you're going broke in Iowa.(starting to getRay, we're behind on the mortgage. That field ate up our savings. We could lose the farm.No. This is too much.- I understand your need to prove to the world you're not turning into your father, but you've done it! You believed in the magic, and it came true. Isn't that enough?What. Just tell me what it is.Fenway Park... Is that the one with the big green wall in left field?I dreamt last night you were at Fenway.Yes...(nods,I'll help you pack..you take that to 93, and then it gets all squiggly, and after that you're on your own. How are you going to find him, anyway? He won't exactly be in the phone book, you know.No, dear. Not for a kidnapping.I'll try to sell the combine. We sure don't need it anymore. Karin runs up, grabs Ray behind each ear and hugs and kisses him.Ray, they're not going to make a pass at me. They're'ghosts.For the same reason I've never pissed on your birthday cake.Ray.Welcome.He'll be able to do more than just practice.Come on. They walk towards the field.Let's enjoy this place while we still have it.Once we fell behind in the payments, the full amount of the mortgage became due.Unless we sell.Forget it. They're buying up single farms all around us, make it one big farm. First thing they'll do is plow under your field. Ray just sits there, letting that sink in.Honey, that was Mark. He's coming tonight. He needs a decision tonight.Everything is so perfect here.I know. Suddenly, Ray snaps his head to the side, as one does to pick up a-distant sound.Yes.She's talking about people seeing their memories... touching their past.It'll be like one of those tiny, French restaurants that have no sign. You find it by instinct. They'll be drawn.We all can.Should we move her?Is there a doctor? A nurse? Any of you? They sadly shake their heads no. Annie races inside.There's hope for you yet, Mark.You mean 'out'?You go inside and lie down. I'll explain later. Mark walks off toward the people in their cars outside the house.You bet your ass we are. Ray realizes Shoeless Joe is staring at him, with a shit-eating grin on his face.What is it?Introduce him to his granddaughter. Ray cannot believe how wonderful Annie is. The Catcher has reached the edge of the field, and now stands before Ray and Annie.We're going to let you two talk. I have to go look after our guests. Someone's gotta start collecting admission if we're going to keep this place. Very nice meeting you.

SHOELESS JOE.raw_line: It was like having part of me amputated.I've heard that old man wake up and scratch itchy legs that've been dust for fifty years. That was me. I'd wake up in the night with the smell of the ballpark in my nose and the cool of the grass on my feet. The thrill of the grass... He has found the bat he likes.Can you pitch?Not if you can get it near the plate, we don't. Ray smiles, takes a breath and starts his windup, during which he says aloud to himself:Stick with fast balls, kid.Damn, this feels good. Put it right here, huh? Joe holds the bat out low over the plate and Ray pitches it reasonably close to that spot. Jackson hits it out of the park, and beams. Ray brightens up with remembrance.Oh man, I did love this game. You know, I'd have played for food money. it was the game, the sounds, the smells. You ever held a glove or a ball to your face? Ray smiles as he walks in from the mound.And it was riding the trains from town to town. And the hotels with brass spittoons in the lobbies and brass beds in the rooms. And it was the crowd getting to their feet when the ball was hit deep. Shoot, I'd have played for free. The sound of a screen door turns their. attention to the house. Annie and Karin are coming out to them.What's with the lights?Makes it harder to see the ball.Joe. Ma'm...It's okay.Then I guess I'm real.Uh, thanks, but...I don't think I can. Ray and Annie look at Joe for a moment, not quite understanding the ground rules here. Joe senses their discomfort and changes the subject.Hey, can I come back again?There are others, you know. There were eight of us. It'd sure mean a lot to them.Thank you, Ray. I appreciate it. See you later, huh?Hey! Is this heaven?Come on, fellas. Let's hit the showers.Hi, Ray, welcome back.Pleasure's mine.With a couple of Cardinals and A's thrown in for good measure. Ty Cobb wanted to play, but none of us could stand the sonofabitch when we were alive, so we told him to stuff it.What the hell you doing on the sidelines? You came here to play ball, didn't you?Go warm up!We dream.Not if we want to come back.Hev rookie! Doc Graham turns.You were good. Only now do Doc Graham's eyes shine with tears. He smiles, and disappears through the door.We're gonna call it a night. We'll see you tomorrow.Hey! You wanna come with us? Ray's jaw drops.Not you. Him.Out there.Come find out.What are you saying, Ray?Is that why you did this? For-you?'If you build it... He nods toward where the catcher is taking off his gear at home plate.' .he will come.' Ray looks at the Catcher. The hairs on the back of his neck begin to stand up.I'm afraid it is, kid. The Catcher is now walking toward Ray.'Go the distance.' When he says those words, Shoeless Joe sounds just like The Voice.No, Ray. It was you. Shoeless joe winks and walks away, disappearing through the door in the outfield fence.

MARK.raw_line: You're going to lose your farm, pal. It is Sunday afternoon, and Annie's family is visiting. her mother, pink-faced and white-dentured, sits ramrod straight in an antique rocking chair. Also present are her brother, Mark, and his wife Dee.Ray, this stupid baseball field is going to bankrupt you. Everybody knows it. All I'm saying is if you wait till you default on your loan, you lose everything. Sell now, my partners'llgive you a more than a fair price and you walk away with a nest egg.What are you holding on to this place for? You've never even liked Iowa. You don't like farming, you don't know the first thing about it ---How could you plow under your major crop?I don't believe this guy. I'm trying to bail him out and he goes off to watch television. Annie stifles a laugh.He used to be so normal.He's drinking, right?Think about what I said. I just want to help.I thought you two were going to watch some game.Eight of what? Ray points to the noisy players on the field.Karin honey... what are you watching?Do you see any baseball men right now?Why didn't you tell him?Annie, you don't have a choice in the matter. Annie looks vertroubldye.Ray, it's time'to put away our little fantasies and come down to earth.And who's that? Babe Ruth? Ray smiles, savoring the moment.Ah, how do you? I'm Michael Jackson.You have no money, you've got a stack of bills to choke a pig, and come fall, you've got no crop to sell. But I have a deal to offer you that will allow you to stay on this land. This has Ray's attention. Mark climbs the bleachers to stand closer to him.Let us buy you out, and we'll leave the house. You can live in it rent free as long as you want.Do you realize what this land is worth?Then you must realize we cannot keep a useless baseball diamond in the middle of rich farmland.Karin, please!You're not listening to this seriously, are you?Why would anybody pay money to come here? Karin looks at her Uncle mark as if he were a simpleton.What the hell is she talking about?Okay, this is all fascinating, but the fact remains that you don't have the money to bring the mortgage up to date, so you still have to sell. I'm sorry, but you have no choice. He produces a document and hands it to Ray with a pen. Ray looks at it. He doesn't know what to do.Just sign the papers, Ray.Listen to me. Tomorrow morning, when the bank opens, they will foreclose.You're broke, Ray. Sell now or lose everything.Ray. You will lose everything and you will be evicted. Ray looks at the paper with dread. He looks at Shoeless Joe and the players. He looks at his family. Then he turns back to Mark. It's decision time.Don't do this, you son of a bitch! There's no cars, no people...You're crazy. You're all bat-shit crazy!You build a baseball field in the middle of nowhere, you sit around here and stare at nothing ---And you've turned your daughter into a goddamn moron!I'm trying to help you, goddamnit! In that split second, they hear a strangled gasp, and see Karin falling forward from the top row of the bleachers.Oh my God, I'm sorry...Annie...I didn't mean to... Karin is unconscious, and seems to be fighting for breath. Ray and Annie's eyes meet in anguish.I saw...A11 of a sudden this kid runs off the field and turns.into...He just... Where'd he...?Where'd all these people come from...?

Mann laughs.I mean you're like a total bumbler. Ray chuckles his reluctant acceptance of the truth.'Bozo the Kidnapper.No, I never slept with her.Whoever you were going to ask me about. Mann rises and heads up the aisle. Ray looks down at the program -- at the handwritten legend of Moonlight Graham, who played one game fifty-seven years ago, but did not get to bat -- and follows Mann out of the ballpark.Where are you goingfrom here?What is it you're not telling me?I wish I had your passion, Ray. Ray opens the passenger door of the Datsun and Mann jumps in. Ray releases the brake and peels out, burning rubber. Veda enters with a piece of paper from a yellow legal pad.What was the umbrella for?Tell me about his wife.No screwing, no drinking, no opium, no illegitimate children. No-midnight abortions, no shady finances. Ray puts down his notes and picks up the Chicago Tribune.Shoeless Joe had a problem. That's why he needed you. This guy doesn't need us. Ray nods.Then why'd you say it?So this is your penance..so the least you can do is bring back his hero. Ray nods.Well now we know what everybody's purpose here is...except mine. Ray looks at him. When he reaches the fence, he turns back to them.I don't have a lot of money, Ray, but maybe I could pitch in a little.That's not what I meant. Maybe the reason you were supposed to find me was so I could help you with this.Don't change the subject.One thing has nothing to do with the other.You're not only stubborn, you're stupid.Ray... Ray looks at Mann.People will come, Ray. They'll come to Iowa for reasons they can't even fathom. They'll turn up your driveway, not knowing for sure why they're doing it, and arrive at your door, innocent as children, longing for the past. 'Of course we won't mind if you look around,' you'll say. 'It's only twenty dollars per person.' And they'll pass over the money without even looking at it. For it is money they have, and peace they lack.They'll walk out to the bleachers and sit in shirtsleeves in the perfect evening, or they'll find they have reserved seats somewhere in the grandstand or along one of the baselines -- wherever they sat when they were children and cheered their heroes. They'll watch the game, and it will be as if they'd dipped themselves in magic waters. The memories will be so thick they'll have to brush them away from their faces.People will come, Ray.The one constant through all the years, Ray, has been baseball. America has rolled by like an`army of steamrollers. It's been erased like a blackboard, rebuilt, and erased again. But baseball has marked the time. This field, this ° game... it's a piece of our past. It reminds us of all that once was good. And that could be again. People will come. People will most definitely come. Mann has moved everyone with the beauty of his words, and the passion in his.voice. Behind him, the assembled ballplayers respectfully applaud.Ray... Ray looks up at Mann, who, with a gentle tilt of the head, directs Ray's attention to the house. Ray looks behind him toward the house.How long?Good night. Joe starts to trot off the field, then he stops and turns back to the bleachers.Come with you?What is out there?Ray, for God's sake, I'm unattached. You've got a family. This takes Ray down a peg or two.There's a reason they chose me, just as there was a reason they chose you to find me.Because, you big jerk, I gave that interview.The one about Ebbets Field. Think of it, Ray: maybe there's an Ebbets Field still floating around out there somewhere. And maybe I'll get to sit in the stands, and watch a twenty-year-old kid with a smooth face and kinky hair try out for the 1948 Dodgers.There's something out there for me, Ray. And what a story it'll make: a man being able to touch the perfect dream.You bet I will. Annie walks Karin over. Ray bends down to Karin's face.-You take care of this family, Ray.
